user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calculate_add_nonce_with_retry:
```c
static bool
calculate_add_nonce_with_retry (struct MHD_Connection *const connection,
                                const char *realm,
                                struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                                char *nonce)
{
  const uint64_t timestamp1 = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
  const size_t realm_len = strlen (realm);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);

#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (0 == MHD_get_master (connection->daemon)->digest_auth_rand_size)
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Random value was not initialised by " \
                 "MHD_OPTION_DIGEST_AUTH_RANDOM or " \
                 "MHD_OPTION_DIGEST_AUTH_RANDOM_COPY, generated nonces " \
                 "are predictable.\n"));
#endif

  if (! calculate_add_nonce (connection, timestamp1, realm, realm_len, da,
                             nonce))
  {
    /* Either:
     * 1. The same nonce was already generated. If it will be used then one
     * of the clients will fail (as no initial 'nc' value could be given to
     * the client, the second client which will use 'nc=00000001' will fail).
     * 2. Another nonce uses the same slot, and this nonce never has been
     * used by the client and this nonce is still fresh enough.
     */
    const size_t digest_size = digest_get_size (da);
    char nonce2[NONCE_STD_LEN (MAX_DIGEST) + 1];
    uint64_t timestamp2;
#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (da))
      return false; /* No need to re-try */
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */
    if (0 == MHD_get_master (connection->daemon)->nonce_nc_size)
      return false; /* No need to re-try */

    timestamp2 = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
    if (timestamp1 == timestamp2)
    {
      /* The timestamps are equal, need to generate some arbitrary
       * difference for nonce. */
      /* As the number is needed only to differentiate clients, weak
       * pseudo-random generators could be used. Seeding is not needed. */
      uint64_t base1;
      uint32_t base2;
      uint16_t base3;
      uint8_t base4;
#ifdef HAVE_RANDOM
      base1 = ((uint64_t) random ()) ^ UINT64_C (0x54a5acff5be47e63);
      base4 = 0xb8;
#elif defined(HAVE_RAND)
      base1 = ((uint64_t) rand ()) ^ UINT64_C (0xc4bcf553b12f3965);
      base4 = 0x92;
#else
      /* Monotonic msec counter alone does not really help here as it is already
         known that this value is not unique. */
      base1 = ((uint64_t) (uintptr_t) nonce2) ^ UINT64_C (0xf2e1b21bc6c92655);
      base2 = ((uint32_t) (base1 >> 32)) ^ ((uint32_t) base1);
      base2 = _MHD_ROTR32 (base2, 4);
      base3 = ((uint16_t) (base2 >> 16)) ^ ((uint16_t) base2);
      base4 = ((uint8_t) (base3 >> 8)) ^ ((uint8_t) base3);
      base1 = ((uint64_t) MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ())
              ^ UINT64_C (0xccab93f72cf5b15);
#endif
      base2 = ((uint32_t) (base1 >> 32)) ^ ((uint32_t) base1);
      base2 = _MHD_ROTL32 (base2, (((base4 >> 4) ^ base4) % 32));
      base3 = ((uint16_t) (base2 >> 16)) ^ ((uint16_t) base2);
      base4 = ((uint8_t) (base3 >> 8)) ^ ((uint8_t) base3);
      /* Use up to 127 ms difference */
      timestamp2 -= (base4 & DAUTH_JUMPBACK_MAX);
      if (timestamp1 == timestamp2)
        timestamp2 -= 2; /* Fallback value */
    }
    digest_reset (da);
    if (! calculate_add_nonce (connection, timestamp2, realm, realm_len, da,
                               nonce2))
    {
      /* No free slot has been found. Re-tries are expensive, just use
       * the generated nonce. As it is not stored in nonce-nc map array,
       * the next request of the client will be recognized as valid, but 'stale'
       * so client should re-try automatically. */
      return false;
    }
    memcpy (nonce, nonce2, NONCE_STD_LEN (digest_size));
  }
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
    if (digest_ext_error (da))
      return false; /* No need to re-try */
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */

if (! calculate_add_nonce (connection, timestamp1, realm, realm_len, da,
                             nonce))

if (! calculate_add_nonce (connection, timestamp2, realm, realm_len, da,
                               nonce2))

static bool
calculate_add_nonce_with_retry (struct MHD_Connection *const connection,
                                const char *realm,
                                struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                                char *nonce)
explanation:
I inspected pointer declarations and uses in the function and selected fragments where non-const pointer types are declared or passed around and where pointers are converted/used in ways that could be made to point to const-qualified types. I did not mark other code fragments because:
- The parameter 'realm' is already const-qualified (const char *realm), so it complies with the rule.
- The local array 'char nonce2[...]' is an internal, modifiable buffer (not a pointer parameter) and is intentionally writable; Rule 8.13 targets pointer declarations that could be const-qualified, not local arrays used as mutable storage.
- Calls to functions like MHD_get_master(...) are uses of returned values; there are no local pointer declarations for those that could be made const in this snippet.
- Uses of timestamp1/timestamp2 and integer temporaries (base1..base4, etc.) are non-pointer entities and not relevant to Rule 8.13.
- The pointer-to-integer cast involving nonce2 is included above because it uses a pointer in a context where const qualification of the pointed-to type may be relevant; other casts in the function do not involve pointer variables that could be const-qualified.

If further context (declarations of calculate_add_nonce, digest_* APIs, or whether connection and da are modified by callees) is provided, the investigation can determine which of the flagged non-const pointer parameters can be safely changed to point to const-qualified types.
